Incident.Summary: Traffic stop. Driver was arrested for DUI / DWI.

Address.StreetName: N/B Rt 301 S/O Jefferson Farm Pl

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: Traffic stop. In-Car Camera Operational, H-26. This incident was recorded on TFC Thomas Body-Worn Camera. Driver: Luis Alberto Revolorio, H/M, DOB: 05/25/1993 Guatemala Passport / No ID: Address: 3510 Hubbard Rd Apt 101, Hyattsville, MD 20785 Vehicle: MD 8BL7763 - 2000 Honda Accord Location: N/B Route 301, S/O Jefferson Farm Place, Waldorf, Charles County, MD Training and Certificates: Trained and certified in administering the Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police and the National Highway Safety Administration. Completed LIDAR and RADAR training through the Maryland State Police. Completed Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (A.R.I.D.E) training in June 2019. Completed Crisis Intervention Training in September 2020. Distinguished Graduate of the Maryland Highway Safety Office and University of Maryland DUI Institute in July 2022. margin-bottom:11px">Recipient of the Maryland Highway Safety Office DUI Award for Consecutive Years (2020 and 2021). NARRATIVE: PHASE 1 VEHICLE IN MOTION On 08/06/2023, at approximately 0205 hours, I, TFC Thomas #7065 of the Maryland State Police was on routine patrol in the area of northbound Route 301, south of Jefferson Farm Place, Waldorf, Charles County, Maryland. At that time, I observed a white Honda Accord bearing Maryland Registration 8BL7763 in lane #2 in front of my vehicle cross halfway over the divided line into lane #3. I also observed the Hondas driver-side front and rear tires cross over the divided line into lane #1 three separate times. I paced the vehicle for three tenths of a mile and obtained a continuous speed of 34 MPH in a 45 MPH zone. I positioned my vehicle behind the Honda, activated my emergency equipment and initiated a lawful traffic stop. PHASE 2 PERSONAL CONTACT As I approached the vehicle, I observed the driver place his head in his hands as if he was in regret. I made contact with the driver and asked him for his license and registration. I immediately observed his pupils were glassy and bloodshot. The driver did not speak English but advised me he did not have a drivers license and only had a Guatemalan passport. The drivers speech was slow and sluggish and he kept repeating the same phrase I was sleep. There was a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from the drivers breath. The driver was identified through his Republica De Guatemala Passport as Luis Alberto Revolorio (H/M, DOB: 05/25/1993). I asked Revolorio if he consumed any alcoholic beverages and Revolorio responded by saying, I was sleep in broken English. There was a language barrier and I could not understand some of Revolorios statements. PHASE 3 PRE-ARREST SCREENING I then asked Revolorio if he would conduct Standardized Field Sobriety Tests and he responded by saying, Yes. Due to the language barrier, I could not ask Revolorio the medical questions. The three tests attempted were the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus, Walk and Turn and the One-Leg Stand tests. Revolorio wore comfortable shoes and clothing and the area had a level flat surface, free of debris and was well-lit. Revolorio advised he had a previous left foot injury. HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (6/6 clues observed) The first test conducted was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test. The tip of my pen was used as the tests stimulus and held 12-15 inches fromRevolorios eyes. Revolorio was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping hishead still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with hiseyes until told to stop. Revolorios pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking.Revolorio advised he understood the instructions. On multiple occasions, due to the language barrier, I observed Revolorio not looking at the pen and moving his head from side to side. I had to repeat the instructions for him to watch the pen with his eyes only. 1.) Lack of Smooth Pursuit Present in Both Eyes. 2.) Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation Present in Both Eyes. 3.) Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees Present in Both Eyes. Vertical Nystagmus Not Present. WALK AND TURN (Did Not Conduct due to Language Barrier / Previous Foot Injury) ONE LEG STAND (Did Not Conduct due to Language Barrier / Previous Foot Injury) I offered Revolorio a Preliminary Breath Test (PBT), to which he agreed with results of .13 BrAC. Based on my training, knowledge and experience as a Maryland State Trooper and in making DUI and DWI arrests, his glassy and bloodshot eyes and the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and Revolorio failing to maintain his lane of travel, I believed Revolorio was too impaired to operate a motor vehicle. I placed Revolorio under arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol at 0221 hours. Revolorio was transported to the Maryland State Police La Plata Barrack for processing. While traveling to the Barrack, Revolorio was advised of his DR-15, Advice of Rights via the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration Spanish Audio on 08/06/2023. While in the Barrack, Revolorio was explained the DR-15, Advice of Rights form, and asked if he had any questions. Revolorio responded by saying, No. At 0258 hours, Revolorio signed the DR-15, Advise of Rights Form and agreed to submit to an Intoximeter test with a result of .14 BrAC. The Intoximeter operator was Cpl. Burroughs #5968 of the Maryland State Police. Revolorio was processed for Driving While Under the Influence of Alcohol Per Se, Driving While Under the Influence of Alcohol and Driving While Impaired by Alcohol. Revolorio was released to a sober driver at the Barrack. Charges: TA 21-902(a1ii) Driving Under the Influence of Alcohol Per Se TA 21-902(a1i) Driving Under the Influence of Alcohol TA 21-902(b1i) Driving While Impaired by Alcohol TA 21-901.1(b) Negligent Driving TA 21-901.1(a) Reckless Driving TA 16-101(a1) Driving Motor Vehicle Without Required License / Author. margin-bottom:11px">TA 21-201(a1) Failure to Obey Properly Placed Traffic Control Device Instr. All events occurred in Charles County, MD. Case Closed.
